frontmatter.title: Fortran - ARM 64-Bit Platform - Modulo Two Integers

children.value: In this section we will be disassembling simple binaries generated by the Fortran high-level language compiled for the 64-bit ARM platform.
Project code for this section is contained in my

program mod_int

        implicit none

        integer         :: a, b, c

        a = 10
        b = 4

        c = MOD(a, b)

end program mod_int
The program displays the contents of the program
. The program creates three integers: a, b, and c.
is assigned the value of 4, and
is assigned the result of the operation
.  MOD() is a Fortran intrinsic function that returns the remainder of the division of
The program is obviously very simple, with no inputs and outputs. The idea is to generate the binary and look at the disassembly to learn about the workings of the 64-bit ARM processor platform.

The chosen test system is my trusty Samsung Chromebook Plus V2, which has a 64-bit ARMv8 processor. This is a very convenient platform for this exercise due to its availability and ease of access from multiple remote systems via SSH.
The program is compiled with the GNU Fortran compiler,
, which is available on the ARM platform. The program is compiled with debugging information using the
option, which allows us to debug the program in GDB and see the source code interspersed with the assembly instructions.
For general edification, we also have
option, an object file with the
option, and object dumps of the object and executable files.
The generic assembly is generated by using the
The object file is generated by using the
The objdump files are generated by using the following command and options:

$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t mod_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t mod_int_Fortran_aarch64_ggdb3 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt
A rundown of the objdump options is shown here:

$objdump 
Usage: objdump <option(s)> <file(s)>
 Display information from object <file(s)>.
 At least one of the following switches must be given:
  -a, --archive-headers    Display archive header information
  -f, --file-headers       Display the contents of the overall file header
  -p, --private-headers    Display object format specific file header contents
  -P, --private=OPT,OPT... Display object format specific contents
  -h, --[section-]headers  Display the contents of the section headers
  -x, --all-headers        Display the contents of all headers
  -d, --disassemble        Display assembler contents of executable sections
  -D, --disassemble-all    Display assembler contents of all sections
      --disassemble=<sym>  Display assembler contents from <sym>
  -S, --source             Intermix source code with disassembly
      --source-comment[=<txt>] Prefix lines of source code with <txt>
  -s, --full-contents      Display the full contents of all sections requested
  -g, --debugging          Display debug information in object file
  -e, --debugging-tags     Display debug information using ctags style
  -G, --stabs              Display (in raw form) any STABS info in the file
  -W, --dwarf[a/=abbrev, A/=addr, r/=aranges, c/=cu_index, L/=decodedline,
              f/=frames, F/=frames-interp, g/=gdb_index, i/=info, o/=loc,
              m/=macro, p/=pubnames, t/=pubtypes, R/=Ranges, l/=rawline,
              s/=str, O/=str-offsets, u/=trace_abbrev, T/=trace_aranges,
              U/=trace_info]
                           Display the contents of DWARF debug sections
  -Wk,--dwarf=links        Display the contents of sections that link to
                            separate debuginfo files
  -WK,--dwarf=follow-links
                           Follow links to separate debug info files (default)
  -WN,--dwarf=no-follow-links
                           Do not follow links to separate debug info files
  -L, --process-links      Display the contents of non-debug sections in
                            separate debuginfo files.  (Implies -WK)
      --ctf[=SECTION]      Display CTF info from SECTION, (default `.ctf')
      --sframe[=SECTION]   Display SFrame info from SECTION, (default '.sframe')
  -t, --syms               Display the contents of the symbol table(s)
  -T, --dynamic-syms       Display the contents of the dynamic symbol table
  -r, --reloc              Display the relocation entries in the file
  -R, --dynamic-reloc      Display the dynamic relocation entries in the file
  @<file>                  Read options from <file>
  -v, --version            Display this program's version number
  -i, --info               List object formats and architectures supported
  -H, --help               Display this information
We will now disassemble this program on the 64-bit ARM platform and step through the assembly instructions.
When we look at the executable’s objdump, we notice that there are two functions of interest, one is
. The Fortran compiler sets up the program arguments and options in
, while the actual program is contained within
(that is capital MAIN followed by two underscores).
The following text from the executable’s objdump illustrates this:

Disassembly of section .text:

0000000000000814 <MAIN__>:
program mod_int
 814:	d10043ff 	sub	sp, sp, #0x10

        implicit none

        integer         :: a, b, c

        a = 10
 818:	52800140 	mov	w0, #0xa                   	// #10
 81c:	b9000fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #12]
        b = 4
 820:	52800080 	mov	w0, #0x4                   	// #4
 824:	b9000be0 	str	w0, [sp, #8]

        c = MOD(a, b)
 828:	b9400fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #12]
 82c:	b9400be1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #8]
 830:	1ac10c02 	sdiv	w2, w0, w1
 834:	b9400be1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #8]
 838:	1b017c41 	mul	w1, w2, w1
 83c:	4b010000 	sub	w0, w0, w1
 840:	b90007e0 	str	w0, [sp, #4]

end program mod_int
 844:	d503201f 	nop
 848:	910043ff 	add	sp, sp, #0x10
 84c:	d65f03c0 	ret

0000000000000850 <main>:
 850:	a9be7bfd 	stp	x29, x30, [sp, #-32]!
 854:	910003fd 	mov	x29, sp
 858:	b9001fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #28]
 85c:	f9000be1 	str	x1, [sp, #16]
 860:	f9400be1 	ldr	x1, [sp, #16]
 864:	b9401fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #28]
 868:	97ffffa2 	bl	6f0 <_gfortran_set_args@plt>
 86c:	90000000 	adrp	x0, 0 <_init-0x660>
 870:	9124c001 	add	x1, x0, #0x930
 874:	528000e0 	mov	w0, #0x7                   	// #7
 878:	97ffff9a 	bl	6e0 <_gfortran_set_options@plt>
 87c:	97ffffe6 	bl	814 <MAIN__>
 880:	52800000 	mov	w0, #0x0                   	// #0
 884:	a8c27bfd 	ldp	x29, x30, [sp], #32
 888:	d65f03c0 	ret
 88c:	d503201f 	nop
This disassembly represents the ARM AArch64 machine code for a
Fortran program that performs an integer modulus operation using
, so the operation must be implemented using multiple primitive instructions.

program mod_int
  implicit none
  integer :: a, b, c

  a = 10
  b = 4
  c = MOD(a, b)
end program mod_int
subroutine. Let’s go through it line by line, especially focusing on the
Allocate 16 bytes on the stack for local variables
Here is the key section of interest:

828:	b9400fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #12]      // load a into w0
82c:	b9400be1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #8]       // load b into w1
830:	1ac10c02 	sdiv	w2, w0, w1         // w2 = a / b (integer division)
834:	b9400be1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #8]       // reload b into w1
838:	1b017c41 	mul	w1, w2, w1         // w1 = (a / b) * b
83c:	4b010000 	sub	w0, w0, w1         // w0 = a - (a / b) * b = MOD(a, b)
840:	b90007e0 	str	w0, [sp, #4]       // store result in c

children.html: MOD(a,b)=a−(⌊ab⌋×b)\text{MOD}(a, b) = a - \left(\left\lfloor \frac{a}{b} \right\rfloor \times b\right)MOD(a,b)=a−(⌊ba​⌋×b)

children.value: To compute the modulus, we must do:

children.html: MOD(a,b)=a−((a div b)⋅b)\text{MOD}(a, b) = a - \left(\left( \text{a div b} \right) \cdot b\right)MOD(a,b)=a−((a div b)⋅b)

children.value:
a = (a \div b) \cdot b + (a \mod b)
\Rightarrow
a \mod b = a - (a \div b) \cdot b
children.html: a=(a÷b)⋅b+(amod  b)⇒amod  b=a−(a÷b)⋅ba = (a \div b) \cdot b + (a \mod b) \Rightarrow a \mod b = a - (a \div b) \cdot ba=(a÷b)⋅b+(amodb)⇒amodb=a−(a÷b)⋅b

children.value:
844:	d503201f 	nop
848:	910043ff 	add	sp, sp, #0x10      // restore original stack pointer
84c:	d65f03c0 	ret                   // return
Summary: Why Multiple Instructions Are Needed for

children.label: Summary: Why Multiple Instructions Are Needed for MOD
Because ARM64 lacks a direct mod instruction, the compiler emulates it via:

children.html: MOD(a,b)=a−(⌊ab⌋×b)\text{MOD}(a, b) = a - \left(\left\lfloor \frac{a}{b} \right\rfloor \times b\right)MOD(a,b)=a−(⌊ba​⌋×b)

children.value: Let me know if you’d like a version that works with
This disassembly is in ARM64 (AArch64) assembly language, representing the machine code generated from a simple Fortran program named
. The Fortran source is provided inline for context:

program mod_int
    implicit none
    integer :: a, b, c
    a = 10
    b = 4
    c = MOD(a, b)
end program mod_int
(the remainder of 10 divided by 4). The result is stored but not used further (e.g., no printing or return value), so the program has no visible side effects when run—it simply computes and exits.
The disassembly consists of two main functions:
: This is the compiler-generated name for the Fortran program’s body (common in gfortran). It allocates stack space for the three integers, performs the assignments and modulo operation, and returns.
: The C-style entry point for the executable, which handles command-line arguments, initializes the GNU Fortran (gfortran) runtime library, calls
This code was likely compiled with gfortran (evident from calls to
). It’s unoptimized, as seen in redundant loads (e.g., reloading
after division). The program uses 32-bit operations (
registers) for integers, matching Fortran’s default
operation, which requires multiple instructions because ARM64 lacks a direct signed modulo instruction. Instead, the compiler implements it using signed division (
). This is a standard software emulation of modulo:

is integer division. This approach ensures correct handling of signed integers (e.g., negative values, though not used here), but it’s less efficient than a hypothetical hardware modulo. ARM64 does have unsigned divide-with-remainder (
for multiply-subtract), but for signed operations like Fortran’s
, the compiler opts for this sequence to handle signs properly (using
for signed division). If optimization were enabled (e.g.,
), the compiler might inline constants or reduce redundancies, but here it’s straightforward.
I’ll explain each instruction in detail, including opcode, semantics, context, and binary encoding. ARM64 conventions: Registers
(lower 32 bits); stack grows downward; ABI uses

children.label: Detailed Explanation of MAIN__ (Fortran Program Logic)

children.value: This function allocates 16 bytes on the stack (for three 4-byte integers, padded for 16-byte alignment), assigns values to
via the multi-step sequence, and cleans up. The
, allocating 16 bytes of local stack space. Result written back to
. ARM64 requires manual stack management; allocations must be 16-byte aligned.
; upper bits zeroed). This is a 32-bit move immediate.
. Constants are loaded into registers before storing to memory.
on the stack. Stack offsets are positive from current
as the dividend for the modulo operation.
handles negative numbers by rounding toward zero (Fortran
semantics require this for consistency with positive/negative remainders). No remainder is produced directly.
: First step of modulo: Compute quotient
). This is necessary because ARM64 has no single-instruction signed modulo.
(unsigned) to match Fortran’s signed integer behavior.
for multiplication. This reload is redundant (
), likely due to no optimization; an optimized build might eliminate it.
is integer multiplication, with overflow wrapping (but no issue here).
(quotient times divisor). This reconstructs the largest multiple of
(10 - 8 = 2). Integer subtraction without borrow flags checked.
. This yields the modulo result (2). The multi-step process is needed because:
) only produce the quotient, not the remainder.
For signed modulo, the compiler must ensure the remainder has the sign of the dividend (Fortran
Hardware support for remainder exists in some forms (e.g.,
for multiply-subtract in unsigned contexts), but for signed ops, this sequence is portable and safe.
Alternatives like bit manipulation or loops aren’t efficient for general cases. If
were a power of 2, the compiler might optimize to AND (e.g.,
is constant—unoptimized code doesn’t exploit that.
. Stored but unused—Fortran doesn’t require using variables.
: No operation—advances program counter without effect. Often for alignment (instructions 4-byte aligned) or padding.
: Compiler-inserted; no functional role, possibly after inlining checks.

children.label: Detailed Explanation of main (Program Entry Point)

children.value: This is the runtime wrapper for Fortran executables. It processes args, sets up gfortran, calls
, and exits. Similar to the previous disassembly, with minor address differences.
: Allocates 32 bytes (pre-index subtract), stores frame pointer
: Prologue—saves caller state, allocates for locals (argc at +28, argv at +16).
: Calls gfortran arg setup via PLT (dynamic link).
: Passes args to Fortran runtime for handling (e.g., if program used
: Padding nop, possibly for section alignment.
Overall, the program computes but discards the modulo result. Running it produces no output. The multi-op modulo is a compiler choice for correctness and portability on ARM64.
